April 5, 1967
The Honorable Bob Sikes .n
Room 1112
House Office Building
Washington, D.C.
Dear Mr. Sikest
Representative Harfcey Staggers of West Virginia has introduced a bill
(H.R. 6736), The Public Television Act of 1967, to the House of Representa¬
tives. This bill was given support by Claude Pepper of Florida (H.R. 6845)
and Torbert MacDonald (H.R. 7670) of Massachusetts. The proposed legislation,
in accord with the recommendations of President Johnson, calls for increased
aid to educational television and for the first time, provides for financial
support for non-commercial radio.
Those of us who have worked in educational radio for many years are
aware of the significant role it has to play in education. We have found
that radio can be used as effectively, and in some cases more so, to teach
many things. Not least important, it is far less expensive and perhaps this
is the reason that more attention has not &een given to its support and devel¬
opment. Throughout the country radio is being used in the education of public
school children, university students, and for the continuing education of
adults in the community. Its effectiveness has been demonstrated over and
over again. Here in Florida a plan is being considered for a state-wide radio
network to be made possible by placing an educational radiosstation at each of
the twenty-six junior colleges. Other services to the people of Florida in¬
clude the distribution of program materials by our own station, WFSU-FM, to
commercial stations throughout the state for public service broadcast.
Public recognition of its potential as well as financial support are
needed if radio is to reach its full potential as an instrument of education.
It therefore is important that radio be given equal status with television
in the forthcoming legislation. A Public Broadcasting Act, rather than one
for television with radio riding along would help to accomplish this.
I hope you will keep this in mind and support the full inclusion of radio
in all titles of the propped bill. Mr. Jerrold Sandler, Executive Director of
National Educational Radio, 1346 Connecticut Avenue, NW#in Washington, will be
sending background materials for your use. If you have any further questions
either of us will be happy to discuss them with you.
Sincerely yours.
(Mrs.) Marjorie Newman
Program Director, WFSU-FM
